Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The role of Ralstonia solanacearum effector protein Rsp1281 in bacterial wilt disease
Award.AbstractNarration: Bacterial wilt is one of the most devastating bacterial diseases of plants worldwide, affecting hundreds of plant species including many major crops such as tomato and potato. The bacterial wilt pathogen, Ralstonia solanacearum, is a root-invading, vascular pathogen that employs a specialized secretion system to deliver a collection of "effector" proteins directly into plant cells. Effector proteins are thought to promote disease by interfering with plant defenses. This project will identify plant targets of a conserved effector, Rsp1281/PopS, which is present in most R. solanacearum species, is highly expressed within the plant vasculature and is required for full virulence on several plant hosts. The investigators will use biochemical, microscopic and genomic approaches to identify plant proteins, organelles and pathways that are targeted by this effector. The identification of effector targets of a root-invading pathogen may yield new information about plant defense pathways employed in roots and can be useful for developing wilt resistant crops. Additionally, the majority of the work in this project involves student research, integrating research and education. A total of approximately 100 students will participate in this project, acquiring knowledge and skills that will be important in other STEM courses, in graduate school and for success as future scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacterial wilt is one of the most devastating bacterial diseases of plants worldwide, affecting hundreds of plant species including many major crops such as tomato and potato. The bacteria that cause bacterial wilt are collectively called Ralstonia. These bacteria invade plant roots and make their way to the plant xylem, the tissue that allows water to flow from the roots to the leaves.  Within the xylem, the bacteria block plant water flow, which is thought to lead to wilting of the entire plant.

In order for this bacterium to cause disease, it uses a specialized "molecular needle" called the Type 3 secretion system.  The bacteria build this needle and use it to puncture a plant cell and deliver a collection of bacterial ?effector? proteins directly into plant cells. Effector proteins are important for causing plant disease, but the direct roles of many of them are unknown.

In order to better understand effector proteins of Ralstonia, we examined a collection of them that are found in multiple Ralstonia species. By using a fluorescent protein tag, we examined these proteins in plant cells and found they travel to different parts of the plant cell. Some move to the perimiter of the cell, attacking the cell membrane or walls. Some move to specialized organelles, like the vacuole, and some make their way to the nucleus, where DNA is stored. Now that we know where they go, we can better ask questions about what they are doing there.

In addition, we examined the plant responses to the pathogen, carefully detailing the expression of genes in tomato roots after they are exposed to Ralstonia. We found a core set of genes that are activated in response to this pathogen in diseased plants as well as some that are activated in plants that can resist disease. We hope that future studies on the roles of these genes can help with the development of resistant varietals of tomato and potato.

As is often the case with scientific investigations, our work helped the work of others. We helped identify the role of a chemical called putrescine in this disease and helped in the development of a web portal that researchers an use to examine effector interactions with plant proteins.

Unlike most research, which is done by researchers at large instutions with graduate students, full time employees and postdocs, our work was done only by undergraduates and their professor. Students in the Cell Biology and Microbiology teaching labs were involved. Several undergraduates worked in the research lab during their time in college. This work became a valuable part of training future generations of scientists, of doctors, and of professionals who will now have a solid understanding of the process of biological research.

Finally, in order to expand our efforts beyond the scientific communities, the professor developed a science communication podcast called "Microgreens". The aim of this podcast is to tell stories of microbes, plants and the people who study them. Thus far, almost 2,000 people worldwide have listened to the first few episodes.

Altogether, this project investigated the tools employed by a devastating bacterial pathogen of plants, involved teams of hundreds of undergraduates, and led to communication with thousands worldwide. We hope to continue in these efforts in the future.
